 I have seriously considered your type of ethic, and I agree that the traditional ethic of obligation to everyone except yourself is misguided, but a value system that is all about oneself seems unsatisfying since it seems to me so much meaning and reward comes from being part of something bigger. 
 
 You may very well be right that all behavior is egoistic, but I wonder if the focus always on oneself tends to lead to and unrewarding life short on meaning and achievement. For example, Charles Darwin devoted his life unwaveringly to studying biological organisms to discover the laws governing them. His focus  it seems to me was not on himself, but rather to contributing to science, to discovering the truth. He was personally rewarded with fame and respect, so the consequences of his actions were self-aggrandizing. But if his ethic and focus had been, "I am living for whatever is good for me" he may have slacked off the greater cause and focused more on pleasure-seeking. I don't know if your ethic produces the kind of devotion, sacrifice, and discipline that leads to achievement and greatness--something most egoists would really want I think.

 I was asking, given that your values are not religious, what are they. I was not asking about derivations. Let's be honest; what you are doing here is questioning debating about values that are not religious--that was not the point of this thread. 
 
 And values are not the same as tastes. Tastes generally do not involve weighty consequences, values do. If I adopt a value system to kill every man I see, the consequences are dramatically different than adopting a value that prohibits violence. Whether I prefer chocolate or vanilla ice cream lacks consequence. I imagine most people like myself will use a combination of bases for choosing values. The likely consequences of values would be an important consideration. I imagine we also probably draw on what seems reasonible and sensible as well as traditional notions of right and wrong. I also think people try to choose a value system with a central principle (like altruism or individualism) and then try to adopt accompanying values that are consistent with that central principle. There are some thoughts off the top of my head.
 
 People like me feel that there is no way to prove in any ultimate way that a value is correct. That does not imply that values are completely arbitrary because, for one thing, different values produce different results. We can argue about which values are most supportable even though we can't prove which are best in the ultimate sense.
